A law of composition on a set $M$ is a map from $M \times M$ to $M$. It is characterized by the assignment $(a, b) \longmapsto a \cdot b$ for $(a, b) \in M \times M$, and in many cases, the image of a given pair $(a, b)$ is written as a "product" $a \cdot b$ or $ab$.
The center of a group $G$ is defined as the centralizer of $G$, i.e., as $Z=Z_{G}=\{x \in G ; x s=s x \text { for all } s \in G\} .$
Does the concept of a/an Law of Composition need to be defined for a definition of a/an Center to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation: The definition of the Center of a group $G$ involves the concept of elements $x$ in $G$ commuting with every element $s$ in $G$, i.e., $xs = sx$. This definition inherently uses the operation (law of composition) defined on the group $G$, as it refers to the product $xs$ and $sx$. Without a law of composition, the expressions $xs$ and $sx$ would have no meaning because there would be no operation to describe how elements of $G$ combine. Therefore, the concept of a law of composition is necessary to define the center of a group, as it provides the framework within which elements can interact and thus determines whether they commute with all other elements in the group.
